profileText: A Delegate from Delaware; born in New London, Chester County, Pa., March 19, 1734; was privately taught; engaged as clerk to the prothonotary of the court of common pleas for two years; deputy prothonotary and register for the probate of wills for New Castle County, studying law at the same time; was admitted to the bar in 1755 and commenced practice in New Castle, Del.; appointed deputy attorney general for Sussex County in 1756 and served until 1758 when he resigned; went to England and resumed the study of law at the Middle Temple in London; member of the Delaware House of Assembly 1762-1775 and served as speaker in 1772; appointed one of the three trustees of the loan office for New Castle County in 1764 and served until 1776; member of the Stamp-Act Congress in 1765; appointed by the Governor sole notary for the lower counties of Delaware July 10, 1765; in the same year received the commission of a justice of the peace, of the court of common pleas and quarter sessions, and of the orphans' court for New Castle County; appointed collector of the port of New Castle in 1771; Member of the Continental Congress 1774-1776, 1778-1782 and served as President of Congress in 1781; a signer of the Declaration of Independence; member of the state house of representatives in 1776 and 1777 and served as speaker in the latter year; president of the state of Delaware in 1777; chief justice of Pennsylvania 1777-1799; served in the Revolutionary War; member of the convention of Pennsylvania which ratified the Constitution of the United States December 12, 1787; delegate to the state constitutional convention in 1789; Governor of Pennsylvania 1799-1808; died in Philadelphia, Pa., June 24, 1817; interment in Laurel Hill Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Buchanan, Roberdeau. Life of the Hon. Thomas McKean. Lancaster, Pa.: Inquirer Printing Company, 1890.
Coleman, John M. Thomas McKean: Forgotten Leader of the Revolution. Rockaway, N.J.: American Faculty Press, 1975.
McKean, Thomas. A Calm Appeal to the People of the State of Delaware. Philadelphia: Printed by Zachariah Poulson, Junr. ..., [1793].
------. To the Electors of Philadelphia County. [Germantown?: N.p., 1799].
Peeling, James Hedley. The Public Life of Thomas McKean, 1734-1817. Chicago: N.p., 1929.
Rowe, G.S. Thomas McKean: The Shaping of an American Republicanism. Boulder: Colorado Associated University Press, 1978.

researchRecord.name: 1781, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Thomas McKean to Major General Nathanael Greene written on September 21, 1781. In the letter, Thomas McKean writes concerning an Act of Congress respecting retaliation for the cruelties of the enemy.

researchRecord.name: 1781, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Thomas McKean to Major General Nathanael Greene written on November 2, 1781. In the letter, Thomas McKean writes concerning an Act of Congress respecting the Battle at Eutaw Springs.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1781, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Nathanael Greene to Thomas McKean written on November 28, 1781. In the letter, Nathanael Greene congratulates Thomas McKean on the surrender of Cornwallis.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.description: A license signed by Thomas McKean made out to George Greiss, dated August 18, 1804.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1798, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Thomas McKean to Lord Butler written on April 9, 1798. In the letter, Thomas McKean asks Lord Butler to look after land granted to his daughter Ann in Luzerne County, Pennsylvania.

researchRecord.name: 1806, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Peter Gabriel Muhlenberg to Thomas McKean written on February 21, 1806. In the letter, John Muhlenberg affirms the high quality of Pennsylvania's military equipment.

researchRecord.name: In the Samuel Adams Papers, 1783, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Samuel Adams to Thomas McKean written on April 19, 1783. In the letter, Samuel Adams congratulates Thomas McKean on the end of the Revolutionary War, formally announced that day; introduces Mr. Appleton and Mr. Wendell.

researchRecord.name: In the Delaware General Assembly Records, 1777, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A draft of a document ordering the Trustee of the General Loan-Office to pay Thomas Collins 24/7/11 from the public funds dated May 12, 1777. The draft was written and signed by George Read, as speaker of the Council, and Thomas McKean, as speaker of the Assembly; with Thomas Collins's receipt on the verso.

researchRecord.name: In the Francis Hopkinson Correspondence, 1771-1772, 3 items.
researchRecord.description: The correspondence concerns Francis Hopkinson and Thomas McKean's scheme to obtain an appointment as collector of customs for the port of New Castle, Delaware.

researchRecord.name: In the Pennsylvania Governor Records, 1800, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A gubernatorial pardon for five persons convicted of larceny, signed by Thomas McKean on September 24, 1800.

researchRecord.name: In the Pennsylvania Governor Records, 1808, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: An appointment of Mahlon Dickerson as recorder of the city of Philadelphia, dated July 22, 1808. The appointment is signed by Governor Thomas McKean.

researchRecord.name: In the Pennsylvania Lieutenant Governor's Records, 1765, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A warrant from John Penn from July 10, 1765, authorizing Richard McWilliam to affix the seal to Thomas McKean's appointment as justice of the peace in New Castle.

researchRecord.name: In the Pennsylvania Supreme Court Records, [1780-1791], 1 item.
researchRecord.description: An opinion, given to the Supreme Executive Council of Pennsylvania, regarding the Attorney-General's assisting in the prosecution of any quitam information or other penal action. Signed by justices Thomas McKean, William Attlee, and George Bryan.

researchRecord.name: In the Pennsylvania Surveyor General Records, 1807, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: The appointment of William Cox Ellis as deputy surveyor for Lycoming County. The appointment is signed by Samuel Cochran, Surveyor General, and approved by Governor Thomas McKean.

researchRecord.name: In the Signers of the Declaration of Independence Autograph Collection, 1756-1818, 56 items.
researchRecord.description: Other authors include Thomas McKean.

researchRecord.name: In the United States Continental Congress Committee of Secret Correspondence Records, 1776, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A charter of the brigantine Cornelia,dated February 1, 1776. The charter is signed by members of the committee, including Thomas McKean.

researchRecord.name: In the United States Continental Congress Records, 1781, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A proclamation from October 26, 1781 of Congress establishing 13 December to be a day of thanksgiving. Among the blessings cited as worthy of gratitude are the victory at Yorktown, the capture of Cornwallis and his army, the fine harvest, and the assistance of the French. The proclamation is signed by Thomas McKean as President of Congress.

researchRecord.name: In the Alexander James and George Mifflin Dallas Papers, 1794-1865, 2.8 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include Thomas McKean.

researchRecord.name: 1759-1847, approximately 650 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers of Thomas McKean contain correspondence with prominent people of the time, relating to the events of the Revolution. The papers include letters from George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, John Adams, Samuel Adams, John Laurens, Caesar Rodney, and others, 1759-1847; letters to Thomas McKean's wife, 1775-1806; commissions, diplomas, and miscellaneous documents, 1777-1802; pamphlet, Discourse of a Vacuum, 1752; book of poetry and songs; and Thomas McKean's charges to grand juries on his circuit, 1777-1779.

researchRecord.name: In the Mabel Bayard Collection, 1777-1831, 3 items.
researchRecord.description: This small collection contains a letter from George Washington to Thomas McKean written on October 10, 1777. In the letter, George Washington mentions a proposed attack on Wilmington, Delaware.
